Issues.Title: Functional components with multiple roots don't render properly when used with v-for
Issues.Body:
### Version
2.5.16

### Reproduction link
[https://jsfiddle.net/kb9x8rLf/](https://jsfiddle.net/kb9x8rLf/)

### Steps to reproduce
Create a functional component that returns multiple root elements via an array, i.e.:

```javascript
return [h('span'), h('span')];
```
Then use the functional component alongside `v-for`:

```html
<my-component v-for="item in items" />
```

### What is expected?
It should render the functional component as expected.

### What is actually happening?
The rendered view contains "undefined" for each item in the array.

---
The JSFiddle demonstrates how wrapping the functional component in a `<template>` tag with the `v-for` directive fixes the issue, but the `<template>` tag should not be required for this.  Oddly enough, there are some circumstances where it renders properly. In my use-case, I had no issues with the multiple root elements when I put the component inside a `<table>`, but when I wrapped the component with a `<tbody>` I ran into this issue I'm reporting.

Issues.Title: hydrate method possible to allow clientside vuejs or specific components of a vue ssr page
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
I work in an e-commerce that does a lot of A/B test. Our css and js bundles tend to increase in size and we are always trying to reduce them.

We are now looking into some options for isomorphic templates in js and I think it's curious most of the other ones have a way to hydrate from the client js code.

What I'm looking for here is to send less code to client and only necessary code. Apart from bundle size I'm also considering https://medium.com/dev-channel/the-cost-of-javascript-84009f51e99e

If I use vuejs as framework to write all my templates in server side (code consistency, less time teaching developers multiple technologies and other benefits) I will end up with:
- some static pages (such as documentation or FAQ) 
- some very dynamic pages (search, e-commerce catalogs)
- some hybrid pages (might be such as a static page with a options for signup and search with some validation and/or autocomplete inside)

When I try to create js bundles to send to the customer I'm trying to keep only the necessary js code with tree shaking and import of modules based on components used.

From what I understood from https://ssr.vuejs.org/guide/hydration.html the attribute that will tell vuejs that this application needs to be hydrated is created in the ssr version and is only available in the wrapper element of the application. This means that the only way to do hydration is to send the whole page app (SPA isn't something possible in the following years). If I want to force hydration of specific components I'll have to manually add this attribute to each one myself (a hack that would increase risk of bad implementations).

I like the way [Reactjs has a .hydrate method](https://reactjs.org/docs/react-dom.html#hydrate) or how Svelte [has a hydration flag](https://svelte.technology/guide#hydration). This way I can just ship a small component as part of the js bundle and initialize in the way I want.


### What does the proposed API look like?
As it seems the clientside vuejs doesn't use any extra configuration and only read the attribute right now, I guess this could be done with a flag when creating the Vue instance.

```
var app = new Vue({
  hydrate: true,
  el: '#my-specific-component',
  data: {
    message: 'Hydrated!'
  }
})
```

or maybe this can be done in vue config (at least for my case).

```
Vue.config.hydrate = true;
```

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "hydrate method possible to allow clientside vuejs or specific components of a vue ssr page" (#8460)

Issues.Title: Mute/Turn off <router-view> reactive rendering programatically
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
Suppose an app like `Settings` app in iOS.

We navigate in a path like this: 
Settings -> General -> About This Phone

Then we can navigate in a reversed path by clicking 'back' button on the top left corner.

This "happy path" is easy to implement. But as a nature of web app, user may directly visit any "deep route" via a "deep url" and the "back" button loses its power to navigate through the reverse path:

1. User visits `https://app.example.com/settings/general/about`
2. User clicks back
3. App exits 
*Instead, we want the app to navigate to `/settings/general`*

I have managed to automatically inject the `/settings`, `/settings/general` routes when user directly visits `/settings/general/about`. The problem is these two pages and transitions associated to them show up in this process. 

I need the routing life cycles of auto injected routes, i.e. `/settings`, `/settings/general`,  to be complete to make the later `back` operation possible, but a complete routing life cycle causes the corresponding component to be rendered thus the problem occurred.

If I can mute/turn off the `<router-view>`'s rendering before the automatic injection starts and then turn it on later when the injection ends the problem would be hopefully solved.

### What does the proposed API look like?
```
router.mute()
router.unmute()
```
